Resolution.Text: Consider merging the types defined in 'TransformerEngine' with another namespace.
Sign 'TransformerEngine' with a strong name key.

No valid permission requests were found for assembly 'TransformerEngine'. You should always specify the minimum security permissions using SecurityAction.RequestMinimum. If assembly permission requests have been specified, they are not enforceable; use the PermView.exe tool to view the assembly's permissions.
Add an AssemblyVersion attribute to the 'TransformerEngine' assembly.
Sign 'TransformerGui' with a strong name key.

No valid permission requests were found for assembly 'TransformerGui'. You should always specify the minimum security permissions using SecurityAction.RequestMinimum. If assembly permission requests have been specified, they are not enforceable; use the PermView.exe tool to view the assembly's permissions.
Add an AssemblyVersion attribute to the 'TransformerGui' assembly.
Modify the following catch clauses in 'btnTransform_Click' by catching a more specific exception type or rethrowing the exception : 'Exception'

Rule.Name: Assemblies specify permission requests
Rule.Description: Permission requests prevent security exceptions from being thrown after code in an assembly has already begun executing. With permission requests, the assembly does not load if it has insufficient permissions. This rule will fire if you have specified a permission request incorrectly, or incompletely. If you have specified requests but FxCop reports a violation for this rule, use the PermView.exe tool to view the security permissions in the assembly. An unenforceable permission appears as an empty permission set.
Rule.LongDescription: You should add attributes specifying what permissions your assembly will demand, might demand, and what permissions it does not want granted. For example, the following attribute indicates that an assembly will, at minimum, require read access to the USERNAME environment variable: [assembly:EnvironmentPermissionAttribute(SecurityAction.RequestMinimum, Read="USERNAME")]. To specify permissions that the assembly might demand, use SecurityAction.RequestOptional. To specify permissions that the assembly must not be granted, use SecurityAction.RequestRefuse.

Rule.Name: Assemblies have strong names
Rule.Description: Assemblies with strong names can be placed in the global assembly cache and can be checked for tampering at run time.
Rule.LongDescription: The common language runtime compares the key in the assembly's manifest to the key used to generate the strong name, to ensure that the assembly's bits have not been tampered with.

Rule.Name: Assemblies have version numbers
Rule.Description: Assemblies should use version numbers. The version number is considered part of an assembly's identity.
Rule.LongDescription: Versioning is applied by means of the AssemblyVersion attribute.

Rule.Name: Avoid having a namespace with a small number of types
Rule.Description: A namespace should generally have more than five types.

Rule.Name: System.Exception and System.SystemException are not caught
Rule.Description: You should not catch Exception or SystemException.
Rule.LongDescription: Catching generic exception types can hide run-time problems from the library user, and can complicate debugging. You should catch only those exceptions that you can handle gracefully.
